section.title: Properties File
section.para: Log4sh can be configured with a properties file that is separate from the actual script where the logging takes place. By default, log4sh looks for its properties file called log4sh.properties in the current directory. If the file is located elsewhere or with a different name, log4sh can be configured by setting the LOG4SH_CONFIGURATION environment variable (eg. LOG4SH_CONFIGURATION="/etc/log4sh.conf").

A log4sh.properties file that is completly empty is sufficient to configure log4sh. There will be absolutely no output however (which might just be what is desired). Usually though, some output is desired, so there is at least a recommended minimum configuration file. An explaination of the file follows the example.
In the first line, the root logger is configured by setting the default logging level, and defining the name of an appender. In the second line, the stdout appender is defined as a ConsoleAppender.

table.title: Logging Levels (from most output to least)

row.entry: The &trace; level has the lowest possible rank and is intended to turn on all logging.
The &debug; level designates fine-grained informational events that are most useful to debug an application.
The &info; level designates informational messages that highlight the progress of the application at coarse-grained level.
The &warn; level designates potentially harmful situations.
The &error; level designates error events that might still allow the application to continue running.
The &fatal; level designates very severe error events that will presumably lead the application to abort.
The &off; level has the highest possible rank and is intended to turn off logging.

section.title: Appenders
section.para: An appender name can be any alpha-numeric string containing no spaces.

section.title: Types
section.para: An appender can be set to one of several different types.

row.entry: output sent to a file that rolls over daily
partial; logs written, but not rotated
output sent to a file that rolls over by size
output sent to a remote syslog daemon

section.title: Options
section.para: An appender can take several different options.

row.entry: configure a pattern for the output filename
output filename (special filename of STDERR used for logging to STDERR)
number of old logfiles to keep

section.title: Layouts
section.para: An appender can be configured with various Layouts to customize how the output looks.
An layout has many different options to configure how it appears. These are known as patterns.

row.entry: Used to output the category of logging request. As this is not applicable in shell, the conversion character will always returns 'shell'.

entry.para: Used to output the date of the logging event. The date conversion specifier may be followed by a date format specifier enclosed between braces, but this specifier will be ignored. For example, %d{HH:mm:ss,SSS}, or %d{ISODATE}. The specifier is allowed only for compatibility with log4j properties files.
The default format of the date returned is equavilant to the output of the Unix date command with a format of +%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.
Used to output the file name where the logging request was issued.
The default value is equavilent basename $0.

row.entry: This option is for compatibility with log4j properties files.
Used to output the script supplied message associated with the logging event.
This option is for compatibility with log4j properties files.
Used to output the priority of the logging event.
Used to output the number of seconds elapsed since the start of the script until the creation of the logging event.

entry.para: Used to output the current executing thread. As shell doesn't actually support threads, this is simply a value that can be set that can be put into the messages.i

row.entry: This option is for compatibility with log4j properties files.

Used to output the MDC (mapped diagnostic context) associated with the thread that generated the logging event. The X conversion character must be followed by an environment variable name placed between braces, as in %X{clientNumber} where clientNumber is the name of the environment variable. The value in the MDC corresponding to the environment variable will be output.
The sequence %% outputs a single percent sign.

section.title: Environment Variables
section.para: There are some environment variables that can be used to pre-configure log4sh, or to change some of its default behavior. These variables should be set before log4sh is sourced so that they are immediately available to log4sh.
Here is the full list of supported variables.

entry.para: This variable is used to tell log4sh what the name of (and possibly the full path to) the configuration (a.k.a properties) file that should be used to configure log4sh at the time log4sh is sourced. If the value 'none' is passed, than log4sh will expect to be configured at a later time via run-time configuration.

This variable is used to tell log4sh what prefix it should use when parsing the configuration file. Normally, the default value is 'log4sh' (e.g. 'log4sh.rootLogger'), but the value can be redefined so that a configuration file from another logging frame work such as log4j can be read.
